title: AB 1847
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature amended Section 19851 of the Revenue and Taxation Code to address the low participation rate in the federal Earned Income Tax Credit program, resulting in unclaimed federal dollars by working poor families in California. In 2015, California implemented a state EITC to supplement the federal EITC for low-income working individuals, aiming to increase participation and claim more federal dollars. To alleviate tax burden on working poor individuals and families, enhance their wages, ensure access to federal and state Earned Income Tax Credits, and boost California's economy, the state will provide information on these credits for claiming on tax returns. The act aims to assist eligible taxpayers by providing notices from employers and state agencies about the EITC, and ensuring Californians claim both federal and state EITC. The Revenue and Taxation Code is amended to define "employer" as any California employer subject to providing unemployment insurance to employees. Section 19852 of the Revenue and Taxation Code is amended to define key terms related to unemployment insurance and tax credits, including "employer," "employee," "Federal EITC," and "California EITC." The curr_chunk defines key terms related to tax credits, including "Employee," "Federal EITC," and "California EITC," as well as programs serving those who may qualify for these credits. The curr_chunk specifies state departments and agencies that serve individuals eligible for the federal EITC and California EITC, including programs like free or reduced-price meal programs, California Unemployment Insurance, and the Medi-Cal program. The amendments made to this section will apply to notices required under Section 19853 after the effective date of the act. The amendments to Section 19853 of the Revenue and Taxation Code require employers to notify employees about eligibility for federal and California EITC when providing annual wage summaries. State departments and agencies must inform program recipients annually about potential eligibility for federal and California EITC, either between January and April or during regular contact via various communication methods. State departments and agencies are required to annually notify program recipients about potential eligibility for federal and California EITC through various communication methods. This notification can be provided during regular contact by telephone, mail, electronic communication, or in-person. If direct communication is not possible, departments can use indirect channels to reach eligible individuals. It is important that the notice contains the same language as specified in Section 19854. The employer must provide notification to employees either in person or by mail, including instructions on obtaining IRS and Franchise Tax Board notices, or a notice with similar language as specified in Section 19854. The employer must provide notification to employees in person or by mail, containing language similar to Section 19854. Posting on a bulletin board or sending through office mail is not sufficient. Amendments to this section apply to notices provided after the effective date of the act. Section 19854 of the Revenue and Taxation Code is amended. The amendments to Section 19854 of the Revenue and Taxation Code apply to notices provided after the effective date of the act, regarding the availability of federal and California EITC to employees. Based on your annual earnings, you may be eligible for the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) from the federal government. The EITC is a refundable federal income tax credit for low-income working individuals and families. It does not affect certain welfare benefits like Medicaid, Supplemental Security Income, food stamps, low-income housing, or temporary assistance for needy families. You must file a federal tax return to receive the EITC, even if you don't owe federal taxes. Fill out the EITC form in the federal income tax return booklet for more information on eligibility. To determine eligibility for federal benefits like Medicaid, Supplemental Security Income, food stamps, low-income housing, or temporary assistance for needy families, you must file a federal tax return to receive the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC). Contact the Internal Revenue Service for information on eligibility and necessary forms. The California Earned Income Tax Credit (California EITC) is a refundable state income tax credit for low-income working individuals and families, starting from the 2015 tax year. To claim the California EITC, you must file a California income tax return and complete the California EITC form (FTB 3514), even if you do not owe California taxes. The California EITC is not used to determine eligibility for welfare benefits under California law. For more information on eligibility requirements and how to obtain the necessary forms, contact the appropriate authorities. To claim the California EITC, file a California income tax return and complete the California EITC form (FTB 3514). Contact the Franchise Tax Board for information on eligibility requirements and assistance with filing. The amendments made to this section by the act adding this subdivision will apply to notices provided on or after the effective date of that act.
